statement:
Let $\Delta = \{z: {| z |} < 1\}$ be the open unit disk in the complex
plane ${\mathbb{C}}$. Let $f\colon\Delta\to\Delta$ be a holomorphic
function with $f(0)=0$. Then ${| f(z) |} \le {| z |}$ for all
$z\in\Delta$, and ${| f'(0) |} \le 1$. If the equality
${| f(z) |}={| z |}$ holds for *any* $z\ne 0$ or ${| f'(0) |}=1$, then
$f$ is a rotation: $f(z)=az$ with ${| a |}=1$.

This lemma is less celebrated than the bigger guns (such as the Riemann
mapping theorem, which it helps prove); however, it is one of the
simplest results capturing the “rigidity” of holomorphic functions. No
result exists for real functions, of course.
